H0.text: An increase in available ecological niches was a main force driving extensive speciation when the environment became hospitable to life after the Permian mass extinction.

H1.text: Increase of atmospheric oxygen to present levels was a main force driving extensive speciation when the environment became hospitable to life after the Permian mass extinction.

H2.text: Increase in genetic diversity among surviving organisms was a main force driving extensive speciation when the environment became hospitable to life after the Permian mass extinction.

H3.text: Increase in interbreeding between organisms of different species was a main force driving extensive speciation when the environment became hospitable to life after the Permian mass extinction.

A4.text: Wave-dominated shoreface settings (WDSS) are believed to have served as refugium environments because they appear to have been unusually diverse in the mass extinction's aftermath.

A5.text: The decrease in diversity was probably caused by a sharp increase in extinctions, rather than a decrease in speciation.

A7.text: As genetic diversity is positively correlated with population size the expanded population will have more genetic diversity compared to the ancestral population.

A8.text: The new habitat has a wide availability of niche space.

A9.text: Archosauromorph reptiles, which had already appeared and diversified to an extent in the Permian Period, exploded in diversity as an adaptive radiation in response to the Permian-Triassic mass extinction.

A10.text: The first stem-group teleosts appeared during the Triassic (teleosts are by far the most diverse group of fish today).
